claim: Kant's arguments concerning causation and induction are spurious because they rest on the erroneous assumption that all non-empirical truths are trivial
text: Kant's arguments concerning causation and induction are spurious because they rest on the erroneous assumption that all non-empirical truths are trivial
quote: Those arguments are spurious, we will find, because they all rest on the erroneous assumption that all non-empirical truths are trivial.

claim: Each of Kant's spurious arguments corresponds to a cogent argument that does not involve the assumption that all non-empirical truths are trivial
text: Each of Kant's spurious arguments corresponds to a cogent argument that does not involve the assumption that all non-empirical truths are trivial
quote: At the same time, so we will also find, each of those arguments corresponds to a cogent argument that does not involve that assumption.

claim: Hume's analyses of causation and induction are fallacious
text: Hume's analyses of causation and induction are fallacious
quote: It is argued that those analyses are fallacious, and an attempt is made to identify the relevant fallacies.

claim: A proposition is the non-linguistic entity meant by a complete sentence, not the sentence itself
text: A proposition is the non-linguistic entity meant by a complete sentence, not the sentence itself
quote: By a "proposition" I mean the non-linguistic entity meant by a complete sentence. I do not mean the sentence itself.

claim: Kant's contention that some propositions are both synthetic and a posteriori is the heart of the Critique of Pure Reason
text: Kant's contention that some propositions are both synthetic and a posteriori is the heart of the Critique of Pure Reason
quote: Kant held that some propositions are both synthetic and also a posteriori. (We will soon define these terms.)This contention is the heart of the system of thought set forth in the Critique of Pure Reason.

claim: Kant's contention about synthetic a priori propositions is false and his argument for it is spurious
text: Kant's contention about synthetic a priori propositions is false and his argument for it is spurious
quote: I will now argue that this contention of Kant's is false and that his argument for it is spurious.

claim: Kant's false contention can be turned into a correct one and his spurious argument into a cogent one through terminological changes
text: Kant's false contention can be turned into a correct one and his spurious argument into a cogent one through terminological changes
quote: But I will also argue that Kant's false contention can readily be turned into a correct one and that his spurious argument can readily be turned into a cogent one. Nothing more than a few terminological changes are needed to accomplish this.

claim: The premises of Kant's argument entail the opposite of the thesis that there are synthetic a priori truths
text: The premises of Kant's argument entail the opposite of the thesis that there are synthetic a priori truths
quote: First, I will argue that the premises of Kant's argument turn out to entail the opposite of the thesis that there are synthetic a priori truths.

claim: Kant's premises entail that there are virtually no a priori truths, making him more of an opponent of a priori truth than John Stuart Mill
text: Kant's premises entail that there are virtually no a priori truths, making him more of an opponent of a priori truth than John Stuart Mill
quote: Those premises entail that there are virtually no a priori truths, let alone synthetic a priori truths. Kant turns out to be even more of an opponent of a priori truth than John Stuart Mill.

claim: Kant's reasoning involves confusion about two different epistemological roles of mental imagery
text: Kant's reasoning involves confusion about two different epistemological roles of mental imagery
quote: Second, I will argue that Kant's reasoning involves a confusion concerning the two different epistemological roles that mental imagery can play.

claim: Mental imagery can serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis
text: Mental imagery can serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis
quote: On the one hand, mental imagery can serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis.

claim: Mental images are spatiotemporal phenomena that can be the object of empirical study
text: Mental images are spatiotemporal phenomena that can be the object of empirical study
quote: On the other hand, mental images are spatiotemporal phenomena in their own right, and can thus be the object of empirical study.

claim: Despite problems with synthetic a priori, the important parts of the Critique are successful
text: Despite problems with synthetic a priori, the important parts of the Critique are successful
quote: But I will also argue that, despite the problems just discussed, the important parts of the Critique are a success.

claim: Kant's claims about causality, personal identity, and rationality are correct and founded on cogent arguments
text: Kant's claims about causality, personal identity, and rationality are correct and founded on cogent arguments
quote: Kant's astonishing claims about causality, personal identity, and rationality turn out to be correct and founded on cogent arguments.

claim: Kant's reasoning must be 'de-psychologized' by reinterpreting psychological statements as logical statements
text: Kant's reasoning must be 'de-psychologized' by reinterpreting psychological statements as logical statements
quote: But if this is to be made apparent, Kant's reasoning must be "de-psychologized", i.e. his statements about psychology must be reinterpreted as statements about logic.

claim: The word 'concept' has two meanings - one logical, one psychological
text: The word 'concept' has two meanings - one logical, one psychological
quote: The word "concept" has two meanings – one logical, one psychological.

claim: In 'Little Timmy doesn't have a concept of an irrational number', concept refers to a psychological entity
text: In 'Little Timmy doesn't have a concept of an irrational number', concept refers to a psychological entity
quote: Consider the sentence "Little Timmy doesn't have a concept of an irrational number." In this sentence, the word "concept" refers to a certain kind of psychological entity.

claim: In logical statements about concepts, the word refers to non-psychological, presumably platonic entities
text: In logical statements about concepts, the word refers to non-psychological, presumably platonic entities
quote: Now consider the sentence "for any x, if x falls under the concept triangle, then x falls under the concept closed figure." In this sentence, the word "concept" obviously does not refer to a mental entity of any kind, but rather to some kind of non-psychological, presumably platonic, entity.

claim: A proposition is conceptually necessary if it holds entirely in virtue of facts about concepts in the non-psychological sense
text: A proposition is conceptually necessary if it holds entirely in virtue of facts about concepts in the non-psychological sense
quote: when I describe a proposition as "conceptually necessary", I mean that it holds entirely in virtue of facts about concepts in the non-psychological sense of the word.

claim: The proposition 'triangles have three sides' is conceptually necessary
text: The proposition 'triangles have three sides' is conceptually necessary
quote: Consider the proposition triangles have three sides. It is clear that the truth of that proposition has nothing to do with psychology, since it would be true in a world devoid of sentient beings.

claim: Representational necessity refers to propositions that are necessarily true in virtue of facts about our minds
text: Representational necessity refers to propositions that are necessarily true in virtue of facts about our minds
quote: As we will see, Kant recognizes a different category of necessary truth. In his view, some propositions are necessarily true in virtue of facts about our minds. When I wish to discuss that kind of necessity, I will use the term "representational necessity."

claim: For Kant, a proposition is a priori if it is known in some way other than through empirical work
text: For Kant, a proposition is a priori if it is known in some way other than through empirical work
quote: If a proposition is known to be true in some way other than through empirical work, Kant describes it as "a priori."

claim: 1+1=2 is a priori because knowing its truth doesn't require empirical work
text: 1+1=2 is a priori because knowing its truth doesn't require empirical work
quote: Consider the proposition 1+1=2. To know that is it true, one doesn't do empirical work; one doesn't perform experiments or make observations. 1+1=2 is thus a priori.

claim: For Kant, a priority is a property of our knowledge of propositions, not propositions themselves
text: For Kant, a priority is a property of our knowledge of propositions, not propositions themselves
quote: For Kant, a priority is a property of our knowledge of propositions. Of course, Kant does describe propositions themselves as "a priori." But when Kant does so, he is really making a statement about our knowledge of those propositions.

claim: For Kant, a proposition is a priori based on how one comes to know it, not its intrinsic logical properties
text: For Kant, a proposition is a priori based on how one comes to know it, not its intrinsic logical properties
quote: For Kant, a proposition is a priori not in virtue of its intrinsic or strictly logical properties, but in virtue of facts about how one comes to know it.

claim: A given proposition could be a priori for one creature and a posteriori for another
text: A given proposition could be a priori for one creature and a posteriori for another
quote: A consequence of this conception of a priority – one that Kant himself draws -- is that a given proposition could, in principle, be a priori for one creature and a posteriori for another.

claim: For Kant, a proposition is a posteriori if it is not a priori
text: For Kant, a proposition is a posteriori if it is not a priori
quote: For Kant, a proposition is "a posteriori" if it is not a priori.

claim: 'Smith weighs over 200 lbs' is a posteriori because knowing its truth requires empirical work
text: 'Smith weighs over 200 lbs' is a posteriori because knowing its truth requires empirical work
quote: Consider the proposition Smith weighs over 200 lbs. To know that is true, one must do empirical work. So it is not a priori, and is therefore a posteriori.

claim: Modern usage defines analytic sentences as those whose semantics guarantees their truth
text: Modern usage defines analytic sentences as those whose semantics guarantees their truth
quote: These days the term "analytic" is often used to describe sentences. A sentence is "analytic" exactly if its semantics guarantees its truth.

claim: Kant's official definition: a proposition is analytic if nothing is contained in the predicate which is not contained in the subject
text: Kant's official definition: a proposition is analytic if nothing is contained in the predicate which is not contained in the subject
quote: Kant's official definition of "analytic" is this: a proposition is analytic if "nothing is contained in the predicate which is not contained in the subject."

claim: Quine identified two problems with Kant's definition of analyticity
text: Quine identified two problems with Kant's definition of analyticity
quote: As Quine pointed out, there are two problems with Kant's definition of analyticity.

claim: The notion of containment is left at a metaphorical level
text: The notion of containment is left at a metaphorical level
quote: First, the notion of containment is "left at a metaphorical level." Physical objects can contain other physical objects; but meanings don't contain meanings, at least not in the same sense.

claim: Kant's formulation only applies to statements having subject-predicate form
text: Kant's formulation only applies to statements having subject-predicate form
quote: Second, Kant's formulation only applies to statements having subject-predicate form. So it isn't immediately obvious how to apply it to statements not having that form, for example: A=A or if p implies q, then p implies anything that q implies.

claim: Kant's formulation can be adapted by focusing on whether concepts guarantee truth
text: Kant's formulation can be adapted by focusing on whether concepts guarantee truth
quote: But it isn't hard to adapt Kant's formulation to meet these two objections. Consider the proposition: a+b is larger than a. This proposition is composed of various concepts – a+b, larger than, and so on. By themselves, the structures of these concepts guarantee that a+b is larger than a is true.

claim: For Kant, a proposition is analytic exactly if it is conceptually true
text: For Kant, a proposition is analytic exactly if it is conceptually true
quote: These facts suggest that, for Kant, a proposition is analytic exactly if it is "conceptually true", i.e. exactly if it holds entirely in virtue of facts about the structures of concepts.

claim: Kant's description of A=A as analytic supports the conceptual truth interpretation
text: Kant's description of A=A as analytic supports the conceptual truth interpretation
quote: Consider the proposition A=A. Kant describes this very proposition as analytic. But in so doing, he is not being true to his official definition of analyticity, namely "the predicate is contained in the subject".

claim: A proposition is synthetic a priori if it is known non-empirically but its truth is not guaranteed by conceptual structures
text: A proposition is synthetic a priori if it is known non-empirically but its truth is not guaranteed by conceptual structures
quote: A proposition is a priori if it is known in some way other than through empirical work. A proposition is synthetic if its truth is not guaranteed by the structures of the concepts composing it. A proposition is synthetic a priori if it has both these properties.

claim: According to Kant, 7+5=12 and 'a straight line is the shortest distance between two points' are synthetic a priori truths
text: According to Kant, 7+5=12 and 'a straight line is the shortest distance between two points' are synthetic a priori truths
quote: According to Kant, the propositions 7+5=12 and a straight line is the shortest distance between two points are synthetic a priori truths.

claim: Contrary to Kant, both 7+5=12 and the straight line proposition appear to be analytic
text: Contrary to Kant, both 7+5=12 and the straight line proposition appear to be analytic
quote: But it very much seems that, contrary to what Kant says, both of these propositions are analytic.

claim: The truth of 7+5=12 is guaranteed by the constitutions of the concepts involved
text: The truth of 7+5=12 is guaranteed by the constitutions of the concepts involved
quote: The truth of 7+5=12 seems to be guaranteed by the constitutions of the concepts 7, 5, +, and so on.

claim: Arthur Pap's argument shows that 7+5=12 should be analytic given Kant's premises
text: Arthur Pap's argument shows that 7+5=12 should be analytic given Kant's premises
quote: We find support for this line of thought in argument given by Arthur Pap. 1+1=2 is clearly analytic, as Kant himself acknowledges. 7+5=12 can be shown to follow analytically from 1+1=2 along with some other premises that Kant would regard as analytic.

claim: Analyticity is hereditary with respect to logical consequence
text: Analyticity is hereditary with respect to logical consequence
quote: Anything that follows analytically from an analytic proposition is itself analytic: the property of analyticity is hereditary with respect to the relation of logical consequence.

claim: Kant's reasoning about 7+5 becomes fuzzy due to unclear use of 'concept'
text: Kant's reasoning about 7+5 becomes fuzzy due to unclear use of 'concept'
quote: But at this point, Kant's reasoning becomes fuzzy. The fuzziness is due to the fact that Kant is not clear, either in his thinking or in his exposition, about whether he is using the term "concept" in the logical, or the psychological sense; he goes back and forth.

claim: Kant infers from psychological facts about concept-grasping to logical facts about concepts themselves
text: Kant infers from psychological facts about concept-grasping to logical facts about concepts themselves
quote: From this Kant apparently infers that the concept 7+5 is entirely distinct from the concept =12. But this inference involves a muddle of the two meanings of the word "concept".

claim: Kant's argument requires a principle of conceptual transparency
text: Kant's argument requires a principle of conceptual transparency
quote: For Kant to make his case, he needs to appeal to some principle like the following: the structure of concepts (in the objective sense) of the word can be read off of the way in which they are represented in our minds.

claim: The transparency principle presupposes anti-realism about concepts
text: The transparency principle presupposes anti-realism about concepts
quote: That principle presupposes that concepts are completely transparent: you cannot grasp a concept without at once grasping everything definitive of it. There is no more to them than meets the eye. Their esse lies in their percipi. It thus seems to me that the principle in question presupposes, and is probably motivated by, a kind of anti-realism or psychologism with regard to concepts.

claim: Synthetic a priori propositions raise difficult questions about what makes them true
text: Synthetic a priori propositions raise difficult questions about what makes them true
quote: The very existence of synthetic a priori propositions raises difficult questions. Such propositions do not hold wholly in virtue of facts about the structures of concepts. At the same time, they do not hold in virtue of the kinds of facts that can be discovered through empirical investigation. There thus doesn't seem to be anything left to make them true.

claim: According to Kant, we learn mathematical truths through acts of imagination
text: According to Kant, we learn mathematical truths through acts of imagination
quote: How do you know that 7+5=12? Not through conceptual analysis. Not through the senses. You learn it through an act of the imagination. You imagine seven objects laid next to five other objects, and then see that the resulting aggregate comprises exactly 12 objects.

claim: Kant uses 'intuition' to refer to para-sensory imaging experiences, not conceptual insights
text: Kant uses 'intuition' to refer to para-sensory imaging experiences, not conceptual insights
quote: Kant refers to images of this sort as "intuitions." So it is through "intuition" that you learn the truth of 7+5=12. It must be made clear that Kant is not using this term in the way it is used today. These days, philosophers usually use the term to refer to a putative insight into concepts ("my intuition is that killing someone is morally worse than passively allowing him to die"). This is not what Kant means. By "intuition" Kant means an act of imaging: a kind of para-perception.

claim: Kantian intuitions show representational necessity, not conceptual or empirical necessity
text: Kantian intuitions show representational necessity, not conceptual or empirical necessity
quote: So, for Kant, these para-perceptual experiences show neither empirical truth nor conceptual necessity. What they show is representational necessity. They show us facts, not about the world or about concepts, but about how we must sense-perceive the world.

claim: Intuitions show what we can and cannot represent in imagery
text: Intuitions show what we can and cannot represent in imagery
quote: These para-perceptual experiences show us what we can and cannot represent in imagery. We cannot form an image of a straight line between two points that is longer than some other line between those two points. We cannot form an image of four apples that isn't also an image of two apples and two other apples.

claim: For Kant, representational necessities are psychological rather than conceptual
text: For Kant, representational necessities are psychological rather than conceptual
quote: In Kant's view, these necessities are really of a psychological nature. Our "forms of thought" are such that we must see the world (literally see it) as being such that, in it, parallel lines don't meet, a straight line is the shortest distance between two points, two objects coupled with two other objects make four objects, and so on.

claim: There is no room in Kant's picture for synthetic a priori truth or knowledge thereof
text: There is no room in Kant's picture for synthetic a priori truth or knowledge thereof
quote: Is there any room in this picture for synthetic a priori truth or for knowledge thereof? Both questions must be answered with a "no".

claim: Psychological compulsion to see things a certain way doesn't prove they are that way
text: Psychological compulsion to see things a certain way doesn't prove they are that way
quote: Given only that we are psychologically compelled to see the world as being such that, in it, thus and such is the case, it doesn't follow that thus and such really is the case. A psychotic may be psychologically compelled to see pink elephants, but that doesn't mean there are pink elephants.

claim: Kant admits intuitions only tell us about the phenomenal world, not the noumenal world
text: Kant admits intuitions only tell us about the phenomenal world, not the noumenal world
quote: Actually, Kant himself admits this. These intuitions, he says, tell us about the "phenomenal" world, not the "noumenal" world. By Kant's own definition, the "phenomenal world" is just the world as it appears to us: it is how we see the world. The "noumenal" world is the actual world.

claim: On Kant's view, intuitions give us no knowledge of the external world or concepts
text: On Kant's view, intuitions give us no knowledge of the external world or concepts
quote: So, on Kant's view, intuitions don't tell us anything about the spatiotemporal world and they don't tell us anything about concepts. Thus, given only that intuition tells us that a straight line is the shortest distance between two points, we simply have no reason to believe that straight line is the shortest distance between two points.

claim: Kant's system makes supposedly a priori truths into empirical truths
text: Kant's system makes supposedly a priori truths into empirical truths
quote: So on Kant's view, followed to its logical conclusion, for us to know whether 7+5 really equaled 12, we'd have to learn some fact about the non-mental, non-platonic world (which, for reasons that are internal to Kant's system, Kant says we cannot do). 7+5=12 thus becomes a kind of empirical truth.

claim: Mental imagery can serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis
text: Mental imagery can serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis
quote: When you learn through mental imagery that a straight line intersects a circle at no more than two points, you are learning something that holds entirely in virtue of facts about the structures of the concepts CIRCLE and LINE, and so forth. You are not learning something that holds in virtue of facts about our cognitive machinery.

claim: Kant failed to distinguish different epistemological roles of mental imagery
text: Kant failed to distinguish different epistemological roles of mental imagery
quote: What led Kant astray was a failure to distinguish the different roles that mental imagery can play in the acquisition of knowledge. Kant noted that mental imagery is a kind of para-perception. He concluded from this that, when mental imagery is involved in the discovery of some truth, that truth is synthetic – like those truths that we use perception to discover.

claim: Determining the minimum number of sides a solid can have involves conceptual analysis via imagery
text: Determining the minimum number of sides a solid can have involves conceptual analysis via imagery
quote: If somebody asks me "what is the minimum number of sides a solid can have?", I base my answer on a mental image that I produce. I imagine trying to produce a solid out of four sides, then note that it doesn't work, then try to do the same thing with five sides, and note that it does work. But surely the fact that a solid has to have a minimum of five sides is not synthetic.

claim: Mental imagery can serve different epistemic roles - conceptual analysis vs. empirical observation
text: Mental imagery can serve different epistemic roles - conceptual analysis vs. empirical observation
quote: mental imagery can sometimes serve as a vehicle for conceptual analysis. But it can also play a very different epistemic role. Suppose I want to find out facts about my own psychology. Suppose, for example, that I want to find out whether I can imagine a 17-sided figure. Here I will, of course, generate mental imagery, and attend to the content of that imagery. But in this case, the imagery is not serving as a vehicle for conceptual analysis.

claim: Knowledge about representational limitations is a posteriori
text: Knowledge about representational limitations is a posteriori
quote: For Kant, you learn that you can't represent parallel lines as intersecting by noting that you cannot imagine it; you observe your own mental imagery. So you learn this putative fact about your representational powers through a kind of self-observation, and not through any kind of conceptual analysis. This knowledge turns out to be quite a posteriori.

claim: Leibniz argued that mathematical demonstrations don't derive their cogency from diagrams
text: Leibniz argued that mathematical demonstrations don't derive their cogency from diagrams
quote: But I do not agree with you what seems to be your [Locke's] view, that some kind of general certainty is provided in mathematics by "particular demonstrations" concerning the diagram that has been drawn. You must understand that geometers do not derive their proofs from diagrams, although the expository approach makes it seem so. The cogency of the demonstration is independent of the diagram, whose only role is to make it easier to understand what is meant and to fix one's attention.

claim: Peacocke's distinction between access and justification applies to mental imagery
text: Peacocke's distinction between access and justification applies to mental imagery
quote: When you come to know a logical truth by way of your having a proof of it, you may need to perceive the inscription of the proof, and you may need various perceptual capacities to appreciate that it is a proof. But the justification for your belief in the logical truth is the proof itself. Perceptual experience gives access to the proof, which provides an experience-independent justification for accepting its conclusion.

claim: Transcendental necessity is either psychological or conceptual necessity
text: Transcendental necessity is either psychological or conceptual necessity
quote: In the end, "transcendental" necessity reduces either to mere psychological necessity or to conceptual necessity. We cannot coherently think of a world where triangles have two sides or where 2+2=3. That is because propositions like 2+2=3 and triangles have two sides are conceptually false and consequently draw a limit to what we can conceive of.

claim: Conceptual necessities impose limits on visual representation
text: Conceptual necessities impose limits on visual representation
quote: What cannot be conceived cannot be perceived. Conceptual necessities thus impose sharp limits on how the world can be visually represented. So it is clear how conceptual falsity translates into representational impossibility.

claim: There is an incoherence in Kant's thinking about mathematical propositions
text: There is an incoherence in Kant's thinking about mathematical propositions
quote: There is an incoherence in Kant's thinking more radical than any mentioned so far. He rightly wants to hold that propositions like 7+2=9 and the area of a (Euclidean) triangle is ½ the base×height are a priori. But he also says that we sense-perceive the world as being such that these propositions are true in it.

claim: Mathematical propositions don't describe the spatiotemporal world
text: Mathematical propositions don't describe the spatiotemporal world
quote: But, as Frege clearly stated, 7+2=9 doesn't say anything about the spatio-temporal world; it doesn't say that if you hold up two fingers and then hold up seven fingers, nine fingers are on display. For there could, in principle, be a causal law that falsified just that sort of statement – a law that didn't allow more than five fingers to be simultaneously on display in a certain region.

claim: Kant's position requires mathematical propositions to be both descriptive and non-descriptive of the world
text: Kant's position requires mathematical propositions to be both descriptive and non-descriptive of the world
quote: So Kant's position is self-undermining. He needs mathematical propositions to be two things at once. They must be descriptive of the world: they must say something about beams of light. But they must also not be descriptive of the world: they must not be capable of falsification by anything having to do with beams of light and the like.

claim: If a proposition is necessary, it doesn't describe the empirical world
text: If a proposition is necessary, it doesn't describe the empirical world
quote: But there is an inference from P is necessarily true to P doesn't describe the empirical world (in any way at all). If P is necessary, then P's being true in world 1 doesn't distinguish world 1 from world 2 or from world 897. P therefore doesn't say anything about the world that distinguishes it from other possible worlds.

claim: Kant's conception of analyticity is too narrow, and this is the fundamental error in his system
text: Kant's conception of analyticity is too narrow, and this is the fundamental error in his system
quote: Ultimately, there is one thing wrong with Kant's view: his conception of analyticity is much too narrow. Everything else that is wrong about Kant's position can be traced back to this one mistake. A corollary is that everything that is wrong about his system can be corrected by correcting this one mistake.

claim: Kant grants analytic status only to trivial propositions like 'circles are round'
text: Kant grants analytic status only to trivial propositions like 'circles are round'
quote: Kant grants analytic status only to propositions like (a) circles are round. He denies analytic status to propositions like (b) a circle is a class of points equidistant from a given point in a plane.

claim: Hard analytic truths are logically but not psychologically incoherent to deny
text: Hard analytic truths are logically but not psychologically incoherent to deny
quote: Let us set say that (b) and (e) are "hard analytic", and let us say that (a) and (h) are "easy analytic". It is hard to know that (b) and (e) are true. It is not hard to know (a) and (h) are analytic; a grasp of those propositions by itself suffices for a knowledge of their truth.

claim: What Kant calls synthetic a priori truths are actually hard analytic truths
text: What Kant calls synthetic a priori truths are actually hard analytic truths
quote: What Kant refers to as "synthetic a priori" truths are nothing other than what we are describing as hard analytic truths. What Kant refers to as analytic truths are what we are describing as easy analytic truths.

claim: Recognizing hard analytic truths eliminates the need for psychologistic analysis
text: Recognizing hard analytic truths eliminates the need for psychologistic analysis
quote: Once it is recognized that (b) and (e) are analytic, albeit hard analytic, we must say that they hold entirely in virtue of facts about the concepts that compose them; and there is no longer any temptation to say that they are made true by facts about the mind. So that obliterates any possible warrant that might otherwise be had by Kant's psychologistic analysis of those propositions.

claim: Kant's main concern is understanding how the world must be structured for coherent experience to be possible
text: Kant's main concern is understanding how the world must be structured for coherent experience to be possible
quote: We have experience; we have sequences of thoughts and perceptions that cohere. The world is intelligible to us. We sense-perceive it and about it. Up to a point, our perceptions and thoughts are accurate. In Kant's view, given the very fact that these things are true, we can deduce certain things about the structure of the world.

claim: Transcendental conditions are necessarily satisfied by any world containing entities with coherent thoughts
text: Transcendental conditions are necessarily satisfied by any world containing entities with coherent thoughts
quote: Kant refers to those conditions as "transcendental": they are the conditions that are necessarily satisfied by any world in which there are entities that have coherent, if not always accurate, thoughts and representations.

claim: A transcendental argument has the form: given experience of a certain kind, the world must have certain features
text: A transcendental argument has the form: given experience of a certain kind, the world must have certain features
quote: A "transcendental argument" is one having the form: given only that we have experiences of such and such a kind, it follows that the world must have thus and such features.

claim: There is a hard analytic connection between beings capable of metaphysical questions and propositions about world structure
text: There is a hard analytic connection between beings capable of metaphysical questions and propositions about world structure
quote: I will argue that there is an analytic connection – a hard analytic connection, but an analytic connection no less – between the proposition there exist beings who have the cognitive wherewithal to raise metaphysical questions and propositions concerning the structure of the world itself.

claim: A world without causation would comprise nothing enduring
text: A world without causation would comprise nothing enduring
quote: Imagine a world where there is no causation, where there are merely sequences of events. Such a world would comprise nothing enduring. This is because persistence is itself a causal notion. If something persists, there is ipso facto a causal sequence of some kind.

claim: Coherent ideation requires persistence, which requires causation
text: Coherent ideation requires persistence, which requires causation
quote: Where there is no persistence, there is no coherent ideation. For surely, as a matter of necessity, a coherent thought process involves some kind of persistence. So given only the fact that there are beings who have the ability to raise questions about anything, let alone about the necessary preconditions for experience, it follows that causal relations do not consist in mere sequences of events, but in internal relations of some kind.

claim: This transcendental argument relies on analytic connections, not synthetic a priori truths
text: This transcendental argument relies on analytic connections, not synthetic a priori truths
quote: But notice that this transcendental argument turns on the existence of entirely analytic connections among propositions; no "synthetic a priori" is involved. Given the very concept of a rational thought process, it follows that analytically there are causal relations among events.

claim: Hume's induction problem: past experience cannot justify future expectations without circular reasoning
text: Hume's induction problem: past experience cannot justify future expectations without circular reasoning
quote: Suppose that such and such has always happened in the past. How does our knowledge of that fact warrant our believing that such and such will happen in the future? The warrant is not deductive. Given only that such and such happened before time t, there is no logical contradiction in saying that it won't happen after t.

claim: Justifying induction requires the principle that the future resembles the past, but this is itself empirical
text: Justifying induction requires the principle that the future resembles the past, but this is itself empirical
quote: To have an empirical justification for that inference, we'd have to know that, in general, the future resembles the past and that, consequently, knowledge of the past gives us a rational basis for beliefs about the future. But that is itself an empirical thesis, whose only possible justification lies in our past experience.

claim: Hume's causation problem: there are no logical connections between distinct events
text: Hume's causation problem: there are no logical connections between distinct events
quote: Given two distinct states of affairs, one is not guilty of self-contradiction if one affirms the existence of the one but denies the existence of the other. Since causality holds between distinct states of affairs, there is no strictly logical connection between cause and effect.

claim: Causal forces cannot be empirically justified because we only perceive events, not connections
text: Causal forces cannot be empirically justified because we only perceive events, not connections
quote: We perceive events and regularities among events. If they exist, forces are connections among events, and are not events themselves. What we perceive gives us a basis for believing that certain kinds of events are likely to accompany certain other kinds of events. But what we perceive does not give us any basis for perceiving that things altogether different from events are likely to accompany events.

claim: Hume's position must be qualified: logical relations hold between propositions, not events
text: Hume's position must be qualified: logical relations hold between propositions, not events
quote: Hume says that given any two distinct events, there is no strictly logical connection between them. This must be qualified. Logical relations hold, not between states of affairs, but between pieces of information. Typically, these pieces of information are held to be sentences or propositions.

claim: Whether propositions about events are logically connected depends on how we describe the events
text: Whether propositions about events are logically connected depends on how we describe the events
quote: But this last statement, in its turn, is true only when subject to a heavy qualification. Depending on how we describe A and B, a proposition affirming the existence of the one might entail one affirming the existence of the other.

claim: That simple descriptions don't entail each other doesn't prove events lack internal connections
text: That simple descriptions don't entail each other doesn't prove events lack internal connections
quote: For similar reasons, given only that (*) doesn't entail (**), we cannot infer that A and B have only a contingent relation to each other. What we can infer is either that A is only contingently related to B or that (*) and (**) leave out the relevant data. I believe that (*) and (**) leave out the relevant data, and that the relation between A and B is in no way contingent.

claim: There are no instantaneous states of affairs
text: There are no instantaneous states of affairs
quote: Are there instantaneous states of affairs? Is there anything that exists in three, but not in four, dimensions? Of course, we sometimes speak about instantaneous states of affairs. But, it is now generally held, such talk is elliptical for talk of arbitrarily short, non-instantaneous states of affairs.

claim: Talk of instantaneous properties is elliptical for limit-statements about intervals
text: Talk of instantaneous properties is elliptical for limit-statements about intervals
quote: When we say that such that such and such is what obtains at a given instant t, we mean that what obtains during smaller and smaller intervals containing t approximates arbitrarily well to such and such.

claim: There are no strictly non-dynamic spatiotemporal properties
text: There are no strictly non-dynamic spatiotemporal properties
quote: But exactly similar considerations warrant the view that there can no instantaneous temperature, mass, color, shape, spin, and so on. There are no strictly non-dynamic spatiotemporal properties – no property such that possession of it doesn't involve movement.

claim: No complete description of any state of affairs can avoid temporal duration
text: No complete description of any state of affairs can avoid temporal duration
quote: A corollary is that there is no complete description of any state of affairs that does not say what happens over a stretch of time.

claim: Complete descriptions of events must include descriptions of subsequent events
text: Complete descriptions of events must include descriptions of subsequent events
quote: In that case, a complete description of the occurrences during int would include a description of occurrences happening after int. So a complete description of the relevant mass-energy displacement (the relevant electron-jump or whatnot) would include a description of some later event E.

claim: If complete descriptions include subsequent events, this shatters Hume's view of no necessary connections
text: If complete descriptions include subsequent events, this shatters Hume's view of no necessary connections
quote: This would have two consequences. First it would mean that any description of any given event would include a description of subsequent events. That by itself would shatter Hume's view that there is no necessary connection between any event and any subsequent event.

claim: There would be logical connections between events connected by continuous series
text: There would be logical connections between events connected by continuous series
quote: By this reasoning, there is a strictly logical connection between (complete descriptions of) any two events that are connected by a continuous series of events.
